The following kinases from Table 7 were not included in the in-house panel: GPRK4, PIP5K1A, PIP5K2B, RIOK1, RIOK2, and SRPK1.

    In Vivo Inhibition of μ2 Phosphorylation

    Compound 59 was evaluated for in vivo target engagement by measuring the inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation in the brain. We were particularly interested in confirming the inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation in the brain since, as noted above, in studies with compound 5, it was previously found that AAK1 inhibition in the CNS is the primary site for the antineuropathic pain effect.(23) C57BL6 mice were dosed at 60 mg/kg subcutaneously (sc) with 59, and the in vivo inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation in brain lysates was measured. At 1 h post-treatment, focused beam microwave irradiation was used to inactivate enzyme activity in vivo and euthanize the mice prior to collection of brain lysate. Western blot analysis was used to measure the level of μ2 phosphorylation. Compound 59 effectively reduced μ2 phosphorylation following acute administration. Data presented in Figure 8 show that, when dosed at 60 mg/kg (sc), 59 reduced μ2 phosphorylation to a level similar to that observed in AAK1 knockout mice (82 vs 90% reduction of μ2 phosphorylation, respectively, vs control), suggesting maximal inhibition of AAK1 activity.
    To characterize this effect, both dose–response and time-course studies were conducted. C57BL6 mice were dosed with compound 59 at doses ranging from 0.3 to 60 mg/kg (sc) and were euthanized by microwave irradiation 1 h post-treatment. Data presented in Figure 9A show that 59 dose-dependently inhibited μ2 phosphorylation (13, 56, 62, and 80% reduction in μ2 phosphorylation at 3, 10, 30, and 60 mg/kg at 30 min postdose, respectively, vs control). Statistically significant lowering of μ2 phosphorylation was achieved at doses of 10 mg/kg or higher. In the time-course study, mice were dosed at 30 mg/kg (sc). As shown in Figure 9B, the inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation was rapid (within 15 min), prolonged (up to 2 h), and correlated to plasma levels of the compound. Collectively, these data show that 59 administered subcutaneously can reduce μ2 phosphorylation in the brain. The mean plasma exposures at each dose in the dose–response study were also measured. The mean values were 0.4, 1.2, 2.6, 9.1, 37, and 77 μM at 0.3, 1, 3, 10, 30, and 60 mg/kg, respectively. The EC50 for in vivo inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation in this study was determined to be 8.3 μM (Figure 9C), resulting in an ED50 of 6 mg/kg. In separate studies to evaluate 59 in pain models, the B/P ratio ranged from 0.5 to 0.8 (Kp,uu ranged from 0.7 to 1.0) (vide infra). We also evaluated a poorly brain penetrant AAK1 inhibitor (cellular IC50 = 209 nM, B/P ratio < 0.3) from another chemotype (dosed at 60 mg/kg, sc) (structure and data not shown). The results showed that the poorly brain penetrant compound had no effect on the lowering of μ2 phosphorylation, confirming that the site of action of 59 is in the central nervous system (CNS). These results are in agreement with the lack of in vivo efficacy observed with 7 (B/P ratio 0.007) in a neuropathic pain model.(23)

    Efficacy of Compound 59 in In Vivo Pain Models

    To demonstrate efficacy in preclinical models, compound 59 was tested in the rat formalin model for persistent pain(47) and the rat chronic constriction injury (CCI) model for neuropathic pain.(48) Since efficacy in these models is shown by measurements related to movement, rats treated with 59 were also evaluated in the rotarod test for locomotor activity.
    In the formalin model, injection of dilute formalin into the dorsal surface of the hind paw produces a biphasic spontaneous, nociceptive behavioral response composed of hind paw flinching and licking/biting. The initial response (phase I) occurs within the first few minutes and results from the direct activation of TRPA1 channels on nociceptive c-fiber nerve terminals in the skin.(49) The more persistent phase II response, measured from 11 to 40 min postinjection, is thought to reflect the combined effects of afferent input and central sensitization of dorsal horn neurons in the spinal cord. Rats treated with a subcutaneous (sc) injection of 30 mg/kg of 59 60 min prior to formalin injection showed a significant reduction in phase II hind paw flinching and licking/biting (Figure 10). As expected, phase II behaviors were also significantly reduced by the dual serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor duloxetine (10 mg/kg, sc), which is approved for the treatment of diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, and chronic musculoskeletal pain (Figure 10). Treatment with 59 (30 mg/kg, sc) also significantly reduced phase I flinching (mean ± SEM: vehicle = 225 ± 15; compound 59 = 117 ± 19 (P < 0.001); duloxetine = 72 ± 18 (P < 0.001)) but did not reduce phase I licking/biting duration (vehicle = 25 ± 5; compound 59 = 18 ± 6; duloxetine = 4 ± 3 (P < 0.05)) (data not shown).
    In the CCI model, loose ligatures are tied around the sciatic nerve to simulate the conditions of nerve compression injury.(48) This procedure results in the development of hyperalgesia and allodynia that is typically measured 2–4 weeks after surgery.(50) The effect of acute treatment with 59 was examined on four different measures in CCI rats: (1) thermal hyperalgesia following application of a noxious light source to the plantar surface of the hind paw (Hargreaves test),(51) (2) mechanical hyperalgesia following application of noxious blunt pressure to the paw (Randall–Selitto test),(52,53) (3) cold allodynia following exposure to a surface cooled to a non-noxious 10 °C temperature,(54) and (4) mechanical allodynia following application of an electronic von Frey filament to the plantar surface of the hind paw.(55) In all studies, rats receiving a sham surgery, i.e., the surgical procedure but without ligation of the nerve, were included to determine the control response in nonligated subjects. In the first series of studies, CCI rats were treated with vehicle (sc), compound 59 (60 mg/kg, sc), or the positive comparator gabapentin that was administered orally at a dose of 100 mg/kg (po). In comparison to sham controls, vehicle-treated CCI rats showed a marked reduction in the latency to paw withdrawal following the application of noxious heat consistent with the development of thermal hyperalgesia (Figure 11A). Vehicle-treated CCI rats also showed a marked reduction in the mechanical pressure needed to elicit a nociceptive response (vocalization or withdrawal response) consistent with the development of mechanical hyperalgesia (Figure 11B). Treatment with 59 (60 mg/kg, sc) significantly reduced thermal and mechanical hyperalgesia at all time points examined; the maximal reversal was 113 and 45%, respectively. In comparison, the maximal reversal observed after gabapentin treatment was 89 and 32% for thermal hyperalgesia and mechanical hyperalgesia, respectively (Figure 11).
    Rats receiving CCI surgery also showed a marked reduction in the latency to hind paw withdrawal from a surface cooled to 10 °C and a decrease in the threshold force required to elicit hind paw withdrawal after application of an electronic von Frey filament consistent with the development of cold allodynia and mechanical allodynia (Figure 12). Treatment with 59 (60 mg/kg, sc) significantly reduced cold allodynia and mechanical allodynia at all time points examined; the maximal reversal was 49 and 42%, respectively (Figure 12). In comparison, the maximal reversal observed after gabapentin treatment was 54 and 34% for cold allodynia and mechanical allodynia, respectively (Figure 12).
    Upon completion of each study (∼240 min postdose), plasma and brain tissue samples were collected from a subset of experimental subjects to measure the concentration of 59. Across the four studies, the mean (SD) plasma and brain concentrations after dosing with 60 mg/kg (sc) were 83 (±9) and 39 (±3) μM, respectively, with a B/P ratio of 0.5 (mean Kp,uu = 0.7).
    In the final study, the dose–response to subcutaneous administration of compound 59 was examined in CCI rats with thermal hyperalgesia as the end point. Treatment with 59 significantly reduced thermal hyperalgesia, with 90% reversal achieved at the dose of 30 mg/kg (Figure 13). The minimally effective dose was 3 mg/kg, which produced a significant 35% reversal. In comparison, oral administration of 100 mg/kg gabapentin achieved a maximal 48% reversal of thermal hyperalgesia in this study. At the conclusion of the study (i.e., ∼180 min postdose), plasma and brain samples were collected from a subset of experimental subjects and exposures are reported in Table 9. The mean B/P ratio of 59 in this study was 0.8. Unlike plasma protein binding, brain tissue binding is independent of species and brain origins.(56,57) Thus, on the basis of the mouse unbound fraction in brain tissue homogenate (fu,b), the unbound concentration of 59 in rat brain tissue (Cb,u) was calculated for each dose and the results are shown in Table 9. The mean Kp,uu in this study was 1.0. The unbound concentration of 59 provided a 4-fold or higher coverage over the HEK cell IC50 (51 nM) at doses of 10 mg/kg and higher. In conclusion, 59 was effective at reducing hyperalgesia and allodynia in CCI rats, with efficacy observed at doses of 10, 30, and 60 mg/kg at least comparable or greater than that achieved with gabapentin (100 mg/kg, po).
    Table 9. Mean Plasma and Brain Exposures for Compound 59 in CCI Ratsa
    dose (mg/kg)plasma conc. (μM)brain conc. (μM)plasma unbound conc. (Cp,u) (μM)brain unbound conc. (Cb,u) (μM)
    10.40 ± 0.50.35 ± 0.20.010.01
    31.1 ± 0.30.90 ± 0.30.020.03
    1011 ± 37.0 ± 2.00.220.20
    3052 ± 1133 ± 81.040.92
    a

    Plasma and brain exposures for compound 59 (n = 8) in the dose response study with thermal hyperalgesia as the end point. Results are presented as the mean ± SD.

    Rotarod Assay

    To examine the potential for motor impairment, compound 59 was tested in the accelerating rotarod test in rats. The rotarod assay is widely used to assess motor coordination, balance, and ataxia in rodents(58) and to examine the therapeutic margin between efficacy in preclinical pain models and motor impairment. To exclude differences in motivation and motor learning, rats were trained on the apparatus for 3 consecutive days prior to testing. In addition, a rotarod accelerating at a constant speed from 2 to 20 rotations per minute over a 5 min test period was used to provide a sensitive method to detect motor impairment. Treatment with 59 at doses up to 60 mg/kg sc did not significantly impair accelerating rotarod performance in rats (Figure 14). The average plasma concentrations of 59, determined in a subset of experimental subjects at 190 min postdose, were 7.4, 34, and 84 μM at 10, 30, and 60 mg/kg, respectively. In stark contrast, treatment with gabapentin (100 mg/kg, po) produced a significant rotarod impairment. The profile of gabapentin appears consistent with the drowsiness and dizziness or unsteadiness that have been observed as side effects at clinical doses used for the treatment of neuropathic pain. These results demonstrate that, at doses efficacious in pain models, 59 has a much lower potential to produce motor impairment compared to gabapentin.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Compounds 11–39 were prepared as shown in Scheme 1. Treatment of 65 with toluenesulfonylmethyl isocyanide (TosMIC) in the presence of potassium carbonate followed by reduction of the nitro group afforded 67. Compound 67 was coupled with a series of Boc, Fmoc, or Cbz-protected amino acids in the presence of HATU and N,N-diisopropylethylamine. The Boc protecting group was removed with trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), the Fmoc group was removed with piperidine, and the Cbz group was removed by hydrogenation to furnish compounds 11–34 and 39. Compound 55 (Table 4) was prepared from the corresponding commercially available aniline by treatment of the aniline with Boc-d-leucine in the presence of HATU and N,N-diisopropylethylamine followed by removal of the Boc group with TFA. Alkylation of the amide nitrogen was achieved by heating the product of the coupling of 67 and Boc-d-leucine with methyl iodide in the presence of barium hydroxide to furnish 68. The Boc group was then removed with TFA to provide 35. The synthesis of analogs lacking an amine on the amide side chain was completed as shown in Scheme 1 by the coupling of 67 with various carboxylic acids in the presence of HATU and N,N-diisopropylethylamine to furnish products 36–38.
    The synthesis of (R,R)-40 and (S,S)-40 was carried out as shown in Scheme 2. Palladium catalyzed cross-coupling of 69 and 70 furnished 71 in 55% yield. The pyridine ring and the exocyclic olefin were then reduced by hydrogenation at 50 psi with catalytic platinum(IV) oxide,(59) and the resultant crude product was treated with Boc anhydride to afford 72 in 67% yield over two steps. Hydrolysis of the methyl ester with lithium hydroxide gave 73 in 98% yield, which was then coupled with 67 in the presence of HATU while heating at 40 °C in a tightly capped vial to afford (rac)-74. Removal of the Boc group in (rac)-74 furnished (rac)-40. The Boc-protected intermediate (rac)-74 was separated into its individual enantiomers by chiral HPLC (Chiralcel OD column) followed by the removal of the Boc group on the individual enantiomers ((R,R)-74 and (S,S)-74) to furnish (R,R)-40 and (S,S)-40, respectively. The stereochemical assignment was made on the basis of the results of an X-ray crystal structure of (R,R)-40 bound to AAK1 (Figure 6).
    The analogs to investigate the SAR of the hinge-binding heterocycle were synthesized by the routes depicted in Schemes 3–5. The particular method chosen for each analog generally depended upon the availability of commercial starting materials as well as ease of synthesis. In Scheme 3, commercially available 4-bromo-3-methoxyaniline (75) was coupled with Boc-d-leucine to form 76. Suzuki cross-coupling of 76 with heteroarylboronic acids followed by removal of the Boc group afforded compounds 41, 47, 50, and 54. To prepare thiazole 44, treatment of 76 with bis(pinacolato)diboron in the presence of the PdCl2(dppf)·CH2Cl2 adduct and potassium acetate followed by Suzuki cross-coupling of the resultant pinacol boronate ester with 5-bromothiazole furnished 77. Removal of the Boc group with TFA afforded 44.
    Additional members in a series of heterocyclic replacements for the oxazole moiety were prepared as shown in Scheme 4. Coupling of commercially available 1-bromo-2-methoxy-4-nitrobenzene (78) with ethynyltrimethylsilane in the presence of copper iodide and Pd(PPh3)Cl2 and triethylamine followed by removal of the silyl group with TBAF afforded 79 in high yield. Subsequent heating of 79 in the presence of azidotrimethylsilane provided 80 in 51% yield. Synthesis of the N-methylpyrazole intermediate (81) was completed via a Suzuki reaction of 78 with (1H-pyrazol-4-yl)boronic acid followed by treatment of the resultant product with sodium hydride and iodomethane to give 81. Preparation of the analogs with N-linked heterocycles was carried out by heating 78 with either imidazole or 1,2,4-triazole in the presence of copper iodide, l-histidine, and K2CO3 in DMSO as described by Sreedhar et al.(60) to furnish 82 and 83, respectively. Compounds 85–87 were prepared from heterocycles that were commercially available as either the heteroaryl bromide or chloride. Conversion of 78 to the pinacol boronate intermediate (84) followed by a Suzuki coupling reaction using the conditions indicated in Scheme 4 provided compounds 85–87.(61) Palladium catalyzed cross-coupling of 78 with 3-pyridylboronic acid afforded 88 in 76% yield. Reduction of the nitro group in compounds 80–83, 85, and 88 with palladium on carbon under H2 at 40 psi afforded the respective anilines (89a–89e and 89h). Reduction of the nitro group in 86 was carried out by heating this compound in the presence of zinc and ammonium chloride to give 89f since over-reduction of the pyrimidine group occurred in the presence of H2 and palladium on carbon at 40 psi. The reduction of the nitro group in 87 was completed by heating with tin(II) chloride dihydrate to afford 89g. HATU-mediated coupling of the resultant anilines (89a–89h) with Boc-d-leucine followed by deprotection of the Boc group furnished compounds 42, 43, 45, 46, 48, 49, 51, and 53, respectively.
    Compound 52 was synthesized by the route shown in Scheme 5. A Suzuki coupling reaction of 78 with (2-chloropyridin-4-yl)boronic acid in the presence of PdCl2(PPh3)2 provided 90. A Buchwald coupling reaction of 90 with N,N-methylbenzylamine afforded 91 in 35% yield. Reduction of the nitro group in 91 with tin(II) chloride dihydrate was followed by TBTU-mediated coupling of the resultant aniline with Boc-d-leucine to afford 92 in 88% yield. Removal of the benzyl protecting group was achieved in 66% yield by treatment of 92 with ammonium formate in the presence of 10% palladium on carbon. Removal of the Boc protecting group then furnished 52.
    Replacement of the methoxy group on the central phenyl ring with either a methyl or ethyl group was carried out as shown in Scheme 6. Compound 93, prepared in two steps from 2-bromo-1-methyl-4-nitrobenzene as previously described,(62,63) was treated with TosMIC to furnish 94. Subsequent reduction of the nitro group with tin(II) chloride dihydrate to form the corresponding aniline followed by HATU-mediated coupling with Boc-d-leucine and palladium catalyzed cross-coupling of the bromide with methylboronic acid afforded 95. Boc deprotection of the amine furnished 56 in good yield. Compound 96 was prepared in two steps by Suzuki cross-coupling of 93 with the vinylboronic anhydride pyridine complex to install the vinyl group in 62% yield followed by treatment with TosMIC to form the oxazole ring. Compound 57 was then prepared from 96 via the three-step sequence shown in Scheme 6.
    Replacement of the methoxy group on the central phenyl ring with either an ethoxy or difluoromethoxy group was carried out as shown in Scheme 7. Treatment of 66 with BBr3 at 80 °C resulted in demethylation to furnish 98. Alkylation with either ethyl iodide or methyl 2-chloro-2,2-difluoroacetate furnished 99 and 100, respectively. Compounds 58 and 59 were then prepared via the three-step sequence shown in Scheme 7.
    Compound 60 was synthesized from 4-bromo-3-(trifluoromethoxy)aniline (103)(64) in five steps as shown in Scheme 8. Treatment of 103 with Boc-d-leucine in the presence of HATU afforded the amide product. Stille coupling of the resultant amide intermediate with tributyl(vinyl)stannane in the presence of Pd(PPh3)4 followed by treatment of the resultant olefin with osmium tetroxide and sodium periodate furnished aldehyde 104. Reaction of 104 with TosMIC followed by removal of the Boc group with TFA afforded 60.
    Compound 61 was prepared from 2-fluoro-4-nitrobenzoic acid in six steps as shown in Scheme 9. Reduction of the carboxylic acid in 106 to the alcohol with borane·THF complex followed by Swern oxidation gave 107 in high yield. The oxazole was then installed by treatment of the aldehyde with TosMIC. Reduction of the nitro group by treatment with 10% palladium on carbon under H2 at 40 psi afforded 108. Treatment of 108 with Boc-d-leucine in the presence of HATU followed by removal of the Boc group with TFA furnished 61 in good yield.
    The synthesis of 62 was completed in four steps from 5-(2-bromo-4-nitrophenyl)oxazole (94) as shown in Scheme 10. Coupling of 94 with potassium cyanide in the presence of tributyltin chloride and Pd(PPh3)4 furnished 109 in 52% yield. Selective reduction of the nitro group provided 110 in 83% yield. The synthesis of 62 was then completed in two additional steps.
    Compounds 63 and 64 were prepared by the coupling of 4-(pyridin-4-yl)aniline (111) with either Boc-d-leucine or 73 in the presence of HATU to form the respective amide products (Scheme 11). The Boc protecting group in each compound was removed by stirring with TFA to afford 63 and 64, respectively.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Inhibition of AAK1 represents a potential novel method for the treatment of neuropathic pain, an area of significant unmet medical need. A series of aryl amide-based compounds was identified as selective AAK1 inhibitors. SAR studies resulted in the identification of compound 59, which was used as a tool compound to validate AAK1 as a target for neuropathic pain. An X-ray crystal structure of a closely related analog (19) bound to AAK1 showed that hydrogen bonding interactions occur between the oxazole nitrogen and the backbone NH of Cys129 in the hinge region of the kinase, between the amide NH and Asp194 residue, and between the amine and Asn181 residue. The X-ray crystal structure also revealed the presence of a small lipophilic pocket in the P-loop region of the kinase where a critical hydrophobic interaction resulted in improved potency and kinase selectivity. Screening in an Ambit panel of 391 kinases showed that 59 had good overall kinase selectivity. Compound 59 was evaluated for in vivo target engagement by measuring the inhibition of phosphorylation of μ2. It was found that 59 inhibited μ2 phosphorylation to a level comparable to that observed in AAK1 knockout mice. A dose–response effect was also observed. Compound 59 was efficacious in the formalin model for persistent pain (phase II) in mice and in the CCI model for neuropathic pain in rats. In addition, the level of inhibition of μ2 phosphorylation in the dose–response study strongly correlated with the results of a dose–response study in the rat chronic constriction injury (CCI) of neuropathic pain with thermal hyperalgesia as the end point. Measurement of the plasma and brain concentrations across several studies showed that 59 is a brain penetrant compound (B/P ratio = 0.5–1, Kp,uu = 0.7−1.0). The results obtained from the rotarod model suggest that 59 has the potential to avoid the dose-limiting side effects seen with the current standard-of-care drugs. The in vivo results obtained with 59, in combination with the results previously published with 5, provided our first in vivo proof-of-concept results demonstrating that the AAK1 knockout phenotype can be recapitulated in animals with small molecule AAK1 inhibitors. Moreover, the structural dissimilarity of 59 and 5 provided additional confidence that the observed effects can be attributed to the inhibition of AAK1. Further optimization of AAK1 inhibitors will be reported in due course.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Chemistry Details

    All procedures were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere unless otherwise indicated using anhydrous solvents purchased from commercial sources without further purification. Reactions requiring anhydrous conditions were performed in glassware, which was oven-dried and placed under a nitrogen atmosphere. Normal phase column chromatography was performed on silica gel using a Biotage system and the solvent systems indicated. Solvent systems are reported as v/v percent ratios. Reverse phase chromatography was performed using preparative HPLC instruments (Varian or Shimadzu). All reactions were monitored by TLC using EM Science, 0.25 mm, precoated silica gel plates or by LC/MS. TLC plates were visualized by UV light or staining agents (phosphomolybdic acid, p-anisaldehyde, or KMnO4). For LC/MS monitoring, samples were run on a Shimadzu Nexera series UPLC with a single quadrupole LCMS-2020 mass spectrometer. Yields refer to chromatographically and spectroscopically pure compounds, except as otherwise indicated. Proton NMR spectra were recorded on either a Bruker 400 or 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ values relative to tetramethylsilane. Electrospray ionization (ESI) low-resolution mass spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu Nexera series UPLC with a single quadrupole LCMS-2020 mass spectrometer. Electrospray ionization (ESI) high-resolution mass spectra were obtained on a Finnigan MAT95S or Thermo Scientific MAT900 mass spectrometer. The purity of final products was determined by HPLC. All final products had a purity of ≥95% unless noted otherwise.

    Analytical HPLC Methods

    The following analytical HPLC methods were used for determining the purity of final products.

    Analytical HPLC Method A

    Column: Phenominex Gemini C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 10% methanol/90% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 90% methanol/10% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 0% B to 100% B over 15 min, hold at 100% B for 3 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method B

    Column: Phenominex Luna Phenyl-Hex (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 10% methanol/90% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 90% methanol/10% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 0% B to 100% B over 15 min, hold at 100% B for 3 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method C

    Column: Waters BEH C18 (2.0 × 50 mm, 1.7 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 0% B to 100% B over 3 min, hold at 100% B for 0.5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm; temperature: 50 °C.

    Analytical HPLC Method D

    Column: Waters BEH C18 (2.0 × 50 mm, 1.7 μm); mobile phase A: 5% methanol/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% methanol/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 0% B to 100% B over 3 min, hold at 100% B for 0.5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm; temperature: 50 °C.

    Analytical HPLC Method E

    Column: Waters Sunfire C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: acetonitrile with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 10% B to 95% B over 15 min, hold at 95% B for 5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method F

    Column: Waters Xbridge Phenyl (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: acetonitrile with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 10% B to 95% B over 15 min, hold at 95% B for 5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method G

    Column: Waters C18 Sunfire C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; gradient: 10% B to 100% B over 12 min, hold at 100% B for 3 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 and 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method H

    Column: Waters Phenyl Xbridge C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; gradient: 10% B to 100% B over 12 min, hold at 100% B for 3 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 and 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method I

    Column: Waters C18 Sunfire C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; gradient: 0% B to 50% B over 15 min, 50% B to 100% B over 3 min, hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 and 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method J

    Column: Waters Phenyl Xbridge C18 (4.6 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.05% TFA, pH = 2.5 adjusted with ammonia; gradient: 0% B to 50% B over 15 min, 50% B to 100% B over 3 min, hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 1 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 and 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method K

    Column: Waters Sunfire C18 (3.0 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 10% B to 100% B over 10 min, hold at 100% B for 2 min; flow rate: 0.5 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Analytical HPLC Method L

    Column: Waters Xbridge phenyl (3.0 × 150 mm, 3.5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 10% B to 100% B over 10 min, hold at 100% B for 2 min; flow rate: 0.5 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.

    Preparative HPLC Methods

    The following preparative HPLC methods were used for the purification of final products.

    Prep HPLC Method A

    Column: Waters Sunfire C18 (30 × 150 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 5% B to 50% B over 15 min, 50 to 100% over 3 min, hold at 100% B for 4 min; flow rate: 40 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method B

    Column: Waters XBridge C18 (19 × 200 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 10 to 50% B over 15 min, hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 20 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method C

    Column: Waters Sunfire C18 (30 × 150 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 10% methanol/90% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 90% methanol/10% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 0 to 100% over 20 min, hold at 100% B for 2 min; flow rate: 40 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method D

    Column: Waters XBridge C18 (19 × 200 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 20 to 60% B over 15 min, then hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 20 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method E

    Column: Waters XBridge C18 (19 × 200 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 25 to 65% B over 10 min, then hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 20 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method F

    Column: Waters XBridge C18 (19 × 200 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 10 mM ammonium acetate; gradient: 45 to 85% over 20 min, then hold at 100% B for 5 min; flow rate: 20 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method G

    Column: Waters Xbridge Phenyl (30 × 100 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 0 to 25% B over 15 min; flow rate: 30 mL/min; detector wavelength: 220 nm.

    Prep HPLC Method H

    Column: Waters Sunfire C18 (30 × 150 mm, 5 μm); mobile phase A: 5% acetonitrile/95% water with 0.1% TFA; mobile phase B: 95% acetonitrile/5% water with 0.1% TFA; gradient: 5 to 50% over 15 min, 50 to 100% over 3 min; hold at 100% B for 4 min; flow rate: 40 mL/min; detector wavelength: 254 nm.
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-3-methylbutanamide, TFA (11)
    Step 1: To a solution of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (40 mg, 0.210 mmol), (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)-3-methylbutanoic acid (68.5 mg, 0.315 mmol), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.147 mL, 0.841 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) at room temperature was added HATU (120 mg, 0.315 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 16 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (5 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (25% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/75% hexanes–50% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/50% hexanes; 24 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-3-methyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (56.7 mg, 0.146 mmol, 69% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.32 (br. s., 1H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 7.66 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.53 (br. s., 1H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 6.98 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 5.10 (br. s., 1H), 4.10–4.01 (m, 1H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 2.28 (dq, J = 12.8, 6.5 Hz, 1H), 1.50 (s, 9H), 1.08 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 3H), 1.04 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 3H). MS (ESI) m/z: 390.2 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a solution of (R)-tert-butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-3-methyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (48 mg, 0.123 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 11 (49.8 mg, 0.122 mmol, 99% yield) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 −39.4 (c 0.380, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.69 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.26 (d, J = 3.8 Hz, 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.49 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.38 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.76 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 2.21 (dq, J = 13.3, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 1.02 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H), 1.00 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 290.1494 [(M + H)+, calcd for C15H20N3O3 290.1505]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 12.69 min (method A); >99, tR = 13.13 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)propanamide, TFA (12)
    Compound 12 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)propanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 12 (29 mg, 0.076 mmol, 49% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.64 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.23 (br. s., 3H), 7.70 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 2H), 7.35 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 4.08–3.99 (m, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 1.48 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 262.1181 [(M + H)+, calcd for C13H16N3O3 262.1192]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 11.65 min (method A); >99, tR = 12.47 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)butanamide, TFA (13)
    Compound 13 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)butanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 13 (51 mg, 0.130 mmol, 87% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.67 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.32–8.19 (m, 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.51–7.47 (m, 2H), 7.37 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.93–3.87 (m, J = 5.3 Hz, 1H), 1.88 (quin, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 0.97 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 276.1336 [(M + H)+, calcd for C14H18N3O3 276.1348]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 12.37 min (method A); >99, tR = 12.98 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)pentanamide, TFA (14)
    Compound 14 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)pentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 14 (39 mg, 0.096 mmol, 77% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 −24.1 (c 0.355, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.77 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.27 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.04–3.97 (m, 4H), 2.01–1.86 (m, 2H), 1.53 (dtd, J = 9.7, 7.0, 4.4 Hz, 2H), 1.06 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 290.1507 [(M + H)+, calcd for C15H20N3O3 290.1505]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 13.18 min (method A); >99, tR = 13.73 min (method B).
    (S)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)pentanamide, TFA (15)
    Compound 15 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (S)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)pentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 15 (43 mg, 0.106 mmol, 68% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 +27.4 (c 0.355, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.77 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.27 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.05–3.99 (m, 4H), 2.03–1.87 (m, 2H), 1.59–1.46 (m, 2H), 1.05 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 290.1508 [(M + H)+, calcd for C15H20N3O3 290.1505]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 13.20 min (method A); >99, tR = 13.76 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)hexanamide, TFA (16)
    Compound 16 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)hexanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 16 (39 mg, 0.094 mmol, 62% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 −28.5 (c 0.300, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.68 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.25 (br. s., 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.49 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.37 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.94–3.88 (m, 1H), 1.88–1.78 (m, 2H), 1.39–1.29 (m, 4H), 0.92–0.84 (m, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1653 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O3 304.1661]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 14.07 min (method A); >99, tR = 14.43 min (method B).
    (S)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)hexanamide, TFA (17)
    Compound 17 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (S)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)hexanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford to afford 17 (46 mg, 0.110 mmol, 70% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 +34.0 (c 0.280, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.77 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.27 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 4.06–3.97 (m, 4H), 2.06–1.89 (m, 2H), 1.53–1.38 (m, 4H), 1.03–0.94 (m, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1664 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O3 304.1661]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 14.06 min (method A); >99, tR = 14.51 min (method B).
    (2R,3R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-3-methylpentanamide, TFA (18)
    Compound 18 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (2R,3R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)-3-methylpentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 18 (40 mg, 0.095 mmol, 63% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.67 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.27 (d, J = 4.0 Hz, 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.48 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.38 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.79 (t, J = 5.4 Hz, 1H), 2.01–1.90 (m, 1H), 1.57 (ddd, J = 13.6, 7.5, 3.5 Hz, 1H), 1.25–1.13 (m, 1H), 0.99 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H), 0.90 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1656 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O3 304.1661]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 13.77 min (method A); >99, tR = 14.08 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (19)
    Step 1: To a mixture of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (70 mg, 0.368 mmol), (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (128 mg, 0.552 mmol), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.257 mL, 1.47 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added HATU (210 mg, 0.552 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (5 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (40–70% EtOAc in hexanes) to afford (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (102 mg, 0.253 mmol, 69% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.15 (s, 1H), 8.38 (s, 1H), 7.63 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.52 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.44 (s, 1H), 7.36 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.08 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 4.17–4.09 (m, 1H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 1.72–1.59 (m, 1H), 1.59–1.48 (m, 1H), 1.44 (dd, J = 8.4, 5.2 Hz, 1H), 1.38 (s, 9H), 0.91 (br d, J = 6.5 Hz, 1H), 0.91 (br d, J = 6.3 Hz, 1H). MS (ESI) m/z: 404.3 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a suspension of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (92 mg, 0.228 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.5 mL) at 0 °C was added TFA (0.50 mL, 6.49 mmol). The cooling bath was removed, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature under N2 for 1.5 h. The mixture was concentrated. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 19 (67 mg, 0.161 mmol, 71% yield) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 −34.2 (c 0.250, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.77 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.29 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.05 (dd, J = 7.8, 6.3 Hz, 1H), 4.01 (s, 3H), 1.88–1.75 (m, 3H), 1.07 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1651 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O3 304.1661]. HPLC purity: 99.8, tR = 8.01 min (method E); 99.8, tR = 8.03 min (method F).
    (S)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (20)
    Compound 20 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (S)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 20 (49 mg, 0.117 mmol, 75% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 +34.5 (c 0.280, MeOH). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.71 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.34–8.23 (m, 2H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (s, 1H), 7.48 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.39 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.98–3.92 (m, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 1.73–1.64 (m, 3H), 0.95 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1656 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O3 304.1661]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 13.90 min (method A); >99, tR = 14.16 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-5-methylhexanamide, TFA (21)
    Step 1: To a solution of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (35 mg, 0.184 mmol), (R)-2-((((9H-fluoren-9-yl)methoxy)carbonyl)amino)-5-methylhexanoic acid (101 mg, 0.276 mmol), and N,N diisopropylethylamine (0.129 mL, 0.736 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.5 mL) at room temperature was added HATU (105 mg, 0.276 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 60 h. The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing EtOAc (20 mL). The organic layer was washed with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (5 mL)/water (5 mL) and brine (10 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (30% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/70% hexanes–60% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/30% hexanes; 24 g column) to afford (R)-(9H-fluoren-9-yl)methyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-5-methyl-1-oxohexan-2-yl)carbamate (59.1 mg, 0.110 mmol, 60% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.24 (s, 1H) 8.38 (s, 1H) 7.89 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H) 7.75 (dd, J = 7.3, 3.0 Hz, 2H) 7.71 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H) 7.64 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H) 7.56 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H) 7.45 (s, 1H) 7.44–7.38 (m, 2H) 7.36–7.29 (m, 3H) 4.35–4.19 (m, 3H) 4.15–4.07 (m, 1H) 3.91 (s, 3H) 1.75–1.50 (m, 3H) 1.36–1.25 (m, 1H) 1.25–1.14 (m, 1H), 0.87 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI) m/z 540.3 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a solution of (R)-(9H-fluoren-9-yl)methyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-5-methyl-1-oxohexan-2-yl)carbamate (55 mg, 0.102 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) at room temperature was added piperidine (0.101 mL, 1.02 mmol). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The mixture was concentrated. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method C) and lyophilized to afford 21 (39 mg, 0.089 mmol, 87% yield) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.63 (s, 1H), 8.40 (s, 1H), 8.23 (br. s., 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.51–7.47 (m, 2H), 7.36 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.93–3.87 (m, J = 4.3 Hz, 1H), 1.89–1.79 (m, 2H), 1.56 (dt, J = 13.3, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 1.30–1.22 (m, 2H), 0.89 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3H), 0.88 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 318.1813 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H24N3O3 318.1818]. HPLC purity: >99, tR = 14.66 min (method A); >99, tR = 14.47 min HPLC (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4,4-dimethylpentanamide (22)
    Compound 22 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4,4-dimethylpentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The organic solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous K2CO3. The product was taken up in acetonitrile/water and was lyophilized to afford 22 (80 mg, 0.252 mmol) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 7.25 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.00 (s, 3H), 3.57–3.50 (m, 1H), 2.00–1.90 (m, 1H), 1.52–1.41 (m, 1H), 1.03 (s, 9H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 318.1812 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H24N3O3, 318.1818]. HPLC purity: 97%, tR = 5.90 min (method G); 97%, tR = 6.25 min (method H).
    (R)-N-(3-Methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methyl-2-(methylamino)pentanamide (23)
    Compound 23 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)(methyl)amino)-4-methylpentanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11.     2-(Aminomethyl)-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (24)
    Step 1: To a mixture of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (147 mg, 0.773 mmol) and 2-((benzyloxycarbonylamino)methyl)-4-methylpentanoic acid (180 mg, 0.644 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) at room temperature were added HATU (368 mg, 0.967 mmol) and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.563 mL, 3.22 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution. The aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (40–50% EtOAc in hexanes) to afford benzyl 2-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylcarbamoyl)-4-methylpentylcarbamate (200 mg, 0.443 mmol, 57% yield) as a yellow solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 452.4 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: A mixture of benzyl 2-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylcarbamoyl)-4-methylpentylcarbamate (200 mg, 0.443 mmol), 10% palladium on carbon (236 mg, 0.221 mmol), and ammonium hydroxide (1 mL, 25.7 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was stirred under a H2 atmosphere for 12 h. The catalyst was removed by filtration through a pad of Celite. The filtrate was concentrated, and the product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% 2 M NH3 in MeOH/90% CH2Cl2) to afford 24 (65 mg, 0.205 mmol, 46% yield) as a red solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.16 (s, 1H), 7.66 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.61 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.43–7.39 (m, 1H), 7.19 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 2.94–2.86 (m, 1H), 2.75 (d, J = 11.8 Hz, 1H), 2.66–2.54 (m, 1H), 1.69–1.54 (m, 2H), 1.35–1.25 (m, 1H), 0.96 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 3H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 318.1817 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H24N3O3 318.1818]. HPLC purity: 96%, tR = 11.85 min (method E); 96, tR = 12.85 min (method F).
    (R)-3-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (25)

    Compound 32 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)-3-phenylpropanoic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11.     (R)-2-Amino-3-hydroxy-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)propanamide (33)
    Step 1: To a solution of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (200 mg, 1.05 mmol), (R)-3-(benzyloxy)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)propanoic acid (456 mg, 1.58 mmol), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.735 mL, 4.20 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) at room temperature was added HATU (600 mg, 1.58 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 16 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (5 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (5 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (25% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/75% hexanes–50% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/50% hexanes; 40 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl (3-(benzyloxy)-1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxopropan-2-yl)carbamate (300 mg, 0.642 mmol, 61% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.29 (s, 1H), 8.40 (s, 1H), 7.66 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.56 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.47 (s, 1H), 7.36 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.33–7.25 (m, 5H), 7.12 (br d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 2H), 4.42 (q, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H), 3.92 (s, 3H), 3.67 (qd, J = 9.6, 6.7 Hz, 2H), 1.41 (s, 9H). MS (ESI) m/z: 468.2 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: A solution of (R)-tert-butyl 3-(benzyloxy)-1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-1-oxopropan-2-ylcarbamate (250 mg, 0.530 mmol) in MeOH (25 mL) was stirred for 5 min at room temperature and treated with 10% palladium on carbon (50 mg, 0.05 mmol). The resultant mixture was stirred under 45 psi hydrogen atmosphere for 14 h, after which the mixture was filtered through a pad of Celite. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (4–8% MeOH in CH2Cl2; 24 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl 3-hydroxy-1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-1-oxopropan-2-ylcarbamate (80 mg, 0.212 mmol, 40% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 9.05 (br s, 1H), 7.90 (s, 1H), 7.67 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.53 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 6.98 (dd, J = 8.3, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 5.78 (br d, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.34 (br s, 1H), 4.29–4.22 (m, 1H), 3.96 (s, 3H), 3.82–3.73 (m, 1H), 1.51 (s, 9H). MS (ESI) m/z: 378.0 (M + H)+.
    Step 3: To a solution of (R)-tert-butyl 3-hydroxy-1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-1-oxopropan-2-ylcarbamate (30 mg, 0.079 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) at 0 °C was added TFA, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h at room temperature. Upon completion of the reaction, the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure and the residue was washed with Et2O (2 × 3 mL). The residue was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous Na2CO3 solution (10 mL), and the aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 (5 × 3 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over sodium sulfate and concentrated under reduced pressure to afford 33 (9.5 mg, 0.034 mmol, 43% yield) as an off-white solid, which was isolated as the free base. The product was purified further by preparative reverse phase HPLC (mobile phase: MeOH/water with 20 mM ammonium acetate; column: Waters 19 × 100 mm, C18, 5 μm; λ = 220 nm). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.67 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (s, 1H), 7.26 (dd, J = 8.4, 2 Hz, 1H), 4.01 (s, 3H), 3.84 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 2H), 3.67–3.61 (m, 1H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 278.1135 [(M + H)+, calcd for C13H16N3O4, 278.1141]. HPLC purity: 97%, tR = 7.09 min (method I); 97%, tR = 8.09 min (method J).
    (2R,3S)-2-Amino-3-hydroxy-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)butanamide, TFA (34)
    Step 1: To a solution of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (50 mg, 0.263 mmol) and O-benzyl-N-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-d-threonine (122 mg, 0.394 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.230 mL, 1.314 mmol) followed by HATU (150 mg, 0.394 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 14 h. The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing water (10 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (10 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (30% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/70% hexanes–60% EtOAc with 1% MeOH/40% hexanes; 40 g column) to afford tert-butyl ((2R,3S)-3-(benzyloxy)-1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (120 mg, 0.249 mmol, 95% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.16 (s, 1H), 8.40 (s, 1H), 7.67 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.47 (s, 1H), 7.33 (dd, J = 8.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.31–7.21 (m, 5H), 6.70 (br d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 4.61–4.54 (m, 1H), 4.50–4.43 (m, 1H), 4.26 (br dd, J = 8.9, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 3.96–3.89 (m, 4H), 1.41 (s, 9H), 1.18 (br d, J = 6.0 Hz, 3H). MS (ESI) m/z: 482.2 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a solution of tert-butyl ((2R,3S)-3-(benzyloxy)-1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (105 mg, 0.218 mmol) in MeOH (15 mL) in a Parr bottle was added 10% palladium on carbon (Degussa type) (46.4 mg, 0.022 mmol). The mixture was placed under a H2 atmosphere (45 psi) on the Parr shaker for 14 h. The mixture was filtered through a pad of Celite, and the filtrate was concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (4–8% MeOH in CH2Cl2; 24 g column) to afford tert-butyl ((2R,3S)-3-hydroxy-1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (49.1 mg, 0.125 mmol, 58% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.10 (s, 1H), 8.43–8.35 (m, 1H), 7.65 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.46 (s, 1H), 7.34 (dd, J = 8.7, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 6.48 (br d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 4.89 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 1H), 4.06–4.00 (m, 1H), 3.92 (s, 3H), 1.41 (s, 9H), 1.12 (br d, J = 5.8 Hz, 3H). MS (ESI) m/z: 392.1 (M + H)+.
    Step 3: To a solution of tert-butyl ((2R,3S)-3-hydroxy-1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (35 mg, 0.089 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated and was purified by reverse phase HPLC (method H) and lyophilized to afford 34 (36 mg, 0.089 mmol, 99% yield) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.70 (s, 1H), 8.42 (s, 1H), 8.24 (br d, J = 3.8 Hz, 3H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.54–7.45 (m, 2H), 7.36 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.07 (br t, J = 6.1 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.76 (br t, J = 5.5 Hz, 1H), 1.22 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 292.1297 [(M + H)+, calcd for C14H18N3O4, 292.1297]. HPLC purity: 98.3%, tR = 3.67 min (method K); 99.2%, tR = 4.03 min (method L).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-N,4-dimethylpentanamide (35)
    (R)-tert-Butyl 1-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)(methyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (68) (160 mg, 0.383 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) and cooled to 0 °C. To this solution was added TFA (0.295 mL, 3.83 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the reaction mixture was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% MeOH in CH2Cl2) to afford 35 (115 mg, 0.360 mmol, 94% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.49 (s, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 5.54 Hz, 3H), 7.82 (d, J = 8.31 Hz, 1H), 7.62 (s, 1H), 7.32 (s, 1H), 7.16 (d, J = 8.31 Hz, 1H), 3.97 (s, 3H), 3.93–3.83 (m, 1H), 3.28 (s, 3H), 1.62–1.36 (m, 3H), 0.65 (d, J = 6.30 Hz, 3H), 0.38 (d, J = 6.30 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 318.1819 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H24N3O3 318.1818]. HPLC purity: 95%, tR = 8.04 min (method E); 97%, tR = 8.29 min (method F).
    N-(3-Methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (36)
    To a mixture of 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (50 mg, 0.263 mmol), 4-methylpentanoic acid (45.8 mg, 0.394 mmol), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (0.184 mL, 1.052 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.5 mL) was added HATU (150 mg, 0.394 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (5 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (10 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (40–70% EtOAc in hexanes; 12 g column) to afford 36 (51 mg, 0.177 mmol, 67% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.08 (s, 1H), 8.37 (s, 1H), 7.61 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.43 (s, 1H), 7.28 (dd, J = 8.6, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (s, 3H), 2.33 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 1.62–1.46 (m, 3H), 0.90 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 289.1552 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H21N2O3 289.1552]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 12.81 min (method E); >99%, tR = 11.27 min (method F).
    2-Cyclopentyl-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)acetamide (37)
    Compound 37 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (100 mg, 0.526 mmol) and 2-cyclopentylacetic acid (101 mg, 0.789 mmol) according to the procedure described for the synthesis of 36. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (20–40% EtOAc in hexanes; 25 g column) to afford 37 (65 mg, 0.216 mmol, 41% yield) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.07 (s, 1H), 8.38 (s, 1H), 7.62 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.58 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.30 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 2.37–2.31 (m, 2H), 2.25 (dt, J = 14.8, 7.4 Hz, 1H), 1.83–1.71 (m, 2H), 1.67–1.48 (m, 4H), 1.27–1.14 (m, 2H).     N-(3-Methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-2-phenylacetamide (38)
    Compound 38 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) (20 mg, 0.105 mmol) and 2-phenylacetic acid (22 mg, 0.158 mmol) according to the procedure described for the synthesis of 36.     (R)-N-(3-Methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)piperidine-2-carboxamide, TFA (39)
    Compound 39 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (67) and (R)-1-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)piperidine-2-carboxylic acid according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11.     (rac)-3-Isopropyl-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)piperidine-2-carboxamide, TFA ((rac)-40)
    To a solution of tert-butyl 3-isopropyl-2-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)carbamoyl)piperidine-1-carboxylate ((rac)-74) (45 mg, 0.101 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h.     (2R,3R)-3-Isopropyl-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)piperidine-2-carboxamide, TFA ((2R,3R)-40)
    To a solution of tert-butyl (2R,3R)-3-isopropyl-2-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)carbamoyl)piperidine-1-carboxylate ((2R,3R)-74) (75 mg, 0.169 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford (2R,3R)-40 (75.5 mg, 0.163 mmol, 97% yield) as a white amorphous solid. [α]D22 −22.3 (c 0.275, CHCl3). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.69 (s, 1H), 9.08–8.95 (m, 2H), 8.39 (s, 1H), 7.70 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (s, 1H), 7.46 (d, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 7.35 (dd, J = 8.5, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 4.11 (br. s., 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 3.42 (br. s., 1H), 3.12 (br. s., 1H), 1.98–1.88 (m, 2H), 1.87–1.73 (m, 2H), 1.68–1.59 (m, 2H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 0.88 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 344.1968 (M + H)+, calcd for C19H26N3O3 344.1974]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 14.53 min (method A); >99%, tR = 14.97 min (method B). The absolute stereochemistry was determined by an X-ray crystal structure of (2R,3R)-40 complexed with AAK1.
    (2S,3S)-3-Isopropyl-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)piperidine-2-carboxamide, TFA (2S,3S)-40)
    To a solution of tert-butyl (2S,3S)-3-isopropyl-2-((3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)carbamoyl)piperidine-1-carboxylate ((2S,3S)-74) (82 mg, 0.185 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford (2S,3S)-40 (83.0 mg, 0.180 mmol, 97% yield) as a white amorphous solid. HRMS (ESI) m/z: 344.1969 [(M + H)+, calcd for C19H26N3O3 344.1974]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 14.53 min (method A); >99%, tR = 14.96 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (41)
    Step 1: A mixture of (R)-tert-butyl (1-((4-bromo-3-methoxyphenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (76) (200 mg, 0.482 mmol), 1H-pyrazol-4-ylboronic acid (81 mg, 0.722 mmol), Na2CO3 (2 M aq) (0.722 mL, 1.45 mmol), and tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (27.8 mg, 0.024 mmol) in DME (4 mL) was heated to 90 °C under a N2 atmosphere for 16 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature. The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing water (25 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (25 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (30% EtOAc in hexanes followed by 10% MeOH in CH2Cl2, 12 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)phenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (90 mg, 0.224 mmol, 46% yield) as a yellow solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 403.2 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: (R)-tert-Butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)phenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (70 mg, 0.174 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) and cooled to 0 °C. To this solution was added TFA (1 mL, 12.98 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 41 (18 mg, 0.043 mmol, 25% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.09 (br s, 2H), 7.58 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.19 (dd, J = 8.2, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.05–4.00 (m, 1H), 3.94 (s, 3H), 1.86–1.75 (m, 3H), 1.08 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 3H), 1.06 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 303.1824 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H23N4O2 303.1821]. HPLC purity: 100%, tR = 7.01 min (method E); 100%, tR = 7.01 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(2H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (42)
    Compound 42 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(2H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)aniline (89a) (100 mg, 0.526 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (304 mg, 1.31 mmol) according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11 from 67, except that the HATU-mediated amide forming reaction was carried out at 40 °C. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 42 (76 mg, 0.182 mmol, 40% yield, two steps). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.68 (s, 1H), 8.28 (br s, 3H), 8.16 (br s, 1H), 7.97 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.47 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.34 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 3.95 (d, J = 5.3 Hz, 1H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 1.75–1.63 (m, 3H), 0.95 (d, J = 4.3 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1768 [(M + H)+, calcd for C15H22N5O2 304.1773]. HPLC purity: 100%, tR = 7.44 min (method E); 99.9%, tR = 7.18 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(1-methyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (43)
    Compound 43 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(1-methyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)aniline (89b) (130 mg, 0.640 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (444 mg, 1.92 mmol) according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11 from 67, except that the HATU-mediated amide forming reaction was carried out at 40 °C. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous K2CO3. After concentration, the product was taken up in acetonitrile/water and was lyophilized to afford 43 (67 mg, 0.212 mmol, 46% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.03 (s, 1H), 7.82 (s, 1H), 7.53–7.46 (m, 2H), 7.24 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 3.84 (s, 3H), 3.32–3.28 (m, 1H), 1.81–1.70 (m, 1H), 1.48 (ddd, J = 13.5, 8.2, 5.5 Hz, 1H), 1.37–1.28 (m, 1H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H), 0.89 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 317.1982 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H25N4O2 317.1978]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 7.87 min (method E): >99%, tR = 7.86 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(thiazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (44)
    To a suspension of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(thiazol-5-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (77) (40 mg, 0.095 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1.5 mL) at 0 °C was added TFA (0.50 mL, 6.49 mmol). The cooling bath was removed, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature under N2 for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The organic solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous K2CO3. The product was taken up in acetonitrile/water and was lyophilized to afford 44 (23 mg, 0.070 mmol, 74% yield) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.01 (s, 1H), 8.31 (s, 1H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.60 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.34 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (s, 3H), 3.36 (dd, J = 8.8, 5.5 Hz, 1H), 1.83–1.70 (m, 1H), 1.49 (ddd, J = 13.5, 8.2, 5.5 Hz, 1H), 1.39–1.30 (m, 1H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H), 0.89 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 320.1434 [(M + H)+, calcd for C16H22N3O2S 320.1433]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 7.64 min (method A); >99%, tR = 7.78 min (method B).
    (R)-N-(4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl)-3-methoxyphenyl)-2-amino-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (45)
    Compound 45 was prepared from 4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)-3-methoxyaniline (89c) (180 mg, 0.951 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (330 mg, 1.43 mmol) in two steps in a similar fashion as described for the synthesis of 11 from 67. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 45 (70 mg, 0.168 mmol, 18% yield, two steps) as a green solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 9.21 (br. s., 1H), 7.80 (br. s., 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (br. s., 1H), 7.52 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.38 (dd, J = 8.6, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.06 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (s, 3H), 1.86–1.70 (m, 3H), 1.02 (d, J = 6.3 Hz, 6H).     (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (46)
    Compound 46 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)aniline (89d) (50 mg, 0.263 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (182 mg, 0.789 mmol) in two steps in a similar fashion as described for the synthesis of 11 from 67. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% 2 M ammonia in MeOH/90% CH2Cl2) to afford 46 (60 mg, 0.144 mmol, 55% yield, two steps) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.85 (s, 1H), 8.11 (s, 1H), 7.70 (br. s., 1H), 7.63 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 3.99 (br. s., 1H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 1.78 (d, J = 3.0 Hz, 3H), 1.02 (d, J = 3.8 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 304.1761 [(M + H)+, calcd for C15H22N5O2 304.1773]. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 7.23 min (method E); >99%, tR = 7.17 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (47)
    Step 1: To a mixture of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(4-bromo-3-methoxyphenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (76) (200 mg, 0.482 mmol) and 4-pyridinylboronic acid (65.1 mg, 0.530 mmol) in toluene (4 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) under N2 was added a solution of Na2CO3 (153 mg, 1.445 mmol) in water (1 mL). Tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (27.8 mg, 0.024 mmol) was added, and the reaction was heated at reflux for 12 h. The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing water. The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were concentrated, and the product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10–50% EtOAc in hexanes) to afford (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (151 mg, 0.366 mmol, 76% yield) as a yellow solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 414.3 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a solution of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (150 mg, 0.363 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) at 0 °C was added TFA (1 mL, 13.0 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo and was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The organic solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 to afford 47 (71 mg, 0.227 mmol, 63% yield) as a colorless viscous oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.55 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 7.56 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.51 (dd, J = 4.5, 1.5 Hz, 2H), 7.42–7.32 (m, 2H), 3.79 (s, 3H), 3.38–3.34 (m, 1H), 1.82–1.73 (m, 1H), 1.49 (ddd, J = 13.4, 8.1, 5.4 Hz, 1H), 1.40–1.30 (m, 1H), 0.92 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H), 0.90 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 314.1863 [(M + H)+, calcd for C18H24N3O2 314.1869]. HPLC purity: 97%, tR = 6.18 min (method E); 98%, tR = 6.09 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(pyridazin-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (48)
    Compound 48 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(pyridazin-4-yl)aniline (89e) (142 mg, 0.706 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (490 mg, 2.12 mmol) in two steps in a similar fashion as described for the synthesis of 11 from 67, except that the HATU-mediated amide forming reaction was carried out at 40 °C. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous K2CO3. The product was taken up in acetonitrile/water and was lyophilized to afford 48 (40 mg, 0.123 mmol, 17% yield, two steps) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.42 (br s, 1H), 9.20 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 1H), 7.85–7.78 (m, 1H), 7.61 (s, 1H), 7.52 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 7.44 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 3.84 (s, 3H), 3.45–3.36 (m, 1H), 1.83–1.72 (m, 1H), 1.57–1.47 (m, 1H), 1.44–1.31 (m, 1H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 3H), 0.91 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 315.1803 [(M + H)+, calcd for C17H23N4O2 315.1821]. HPLC purity: 98%, tR = 6.81 min (method E); HPLC 98%, tR = 6.41 min (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(pyrimidin-4-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (49)
    Compound 49 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(pyrimidin-4-yl)aniline (89f) (44 mg, 0.219 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid in two steps in a similar fashion as described for the synthesis of 11 from 67. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 49 (50 mg, 0.117 mmol, 74% yield, two steps) as a yellow amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.77 (s, 1H), 9.22 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 1H), 8.78 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 1H), 8.29 (br. s., 2H), 8.11–8.01 (m, 2H), 7.54 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.41 (dd, J = 8.7, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 3.98 (br. s., 1H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 1.76–1.68 (m, 3H), 0.96 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 6H). MS (ESI) m/z: 315.2 (M + H)+. HPLC purity: >99%, tR = 13.20 min (method A); >99%, tR = 13.61 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(4-(2-chloropyridin-4-yl)-3-methoxyphenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (50)
    Step 1: To a mixture of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(4-bromo-3-methoxyphenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (76) (500 mg, 1.20 mmol), 2-chloropyridin-4-ylboronic acid (208 mg, 1.32 mmol), and tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (69.6 mg, 0.060 mmol) in toluene (6 mL) and ethanol (1.5 mL) under N2 was added a solution of sodium carbonate (383 mg, 3.61 mmol) in water (1 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at reflux for 12 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (25 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 20 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (15 mL), dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (40–50% EtOAc in hexanes; 12 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl 1-(4-(2-chloropyridin-4-yl)-3-methoxyphenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (95 mg, 0.212 mmol, 18% yield) as a white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 448.3 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: (R)-tert-Butyl 1-(4-(2-chloropyridin-4-yl)-3-methoxyphenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (95 mg, 0.212 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) and cooled to 0 °C. To this solution was added TFA (0.163 mL, 2.121 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) and lyophilized to afford 50 (60 mg, 0.130 mmol, 61% yield) as a white amorphous solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.80 (s, 1H), 8.41 (d, J = 5.3 Hz, 1H), 8.31 (br. s., 3H), 7.63 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 1H), 7.56 (dd, J = 5.3, 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.51–7.44 (m, 2H), 7.41–7.36 (m, 1H), 3.97 (d, J = 5.0 Hz, 1H), 3.82 (s, 3H), 1.74–1.64 (m, 3H), 0.94 (d, J = 5.5 Hz, 6H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: 348.1460 [(M + H)+, calcd for C18H23N3O2Cl 348.1479]. HPLC purity: >95%, tR = 9.16 min (method A); >95%, tR = 9.38 min (method B).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(4-(2-aminopyridin-4-yl)-3-methoxyphenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (51)
    Compound 51 was prepared from 4-(4-amino-2-methoxyphenyl)pyridin-2-amine (89g) (130 mg, 0.303 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (116 mg, 0.502 mmol) in two steps in a similar fashion as described for the synthesis of 11 from 67.     2-(4-Aminopiperidin-1-yl)-N-(3-methoxy-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (52)
    Step 1: A mixture of (R)-tert-butyl 1-(4-(2-(benzyl(methyl)amino)pyridin-4-yl)-3-methoxyphenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (92) (110 mg, 0.207 mmol), ammonium formate (65.1 mg, 1.03 mmol), and 10% palladium on carbon (88 mg, 0.083 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was heated at reflux for 2 h. The mixture was filtered through Celite, and the filtrate was concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in CH2Cl2; 25 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(2-(methylamino)pyridin-4-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (60 mg, 0.136 mmol, 66% yield) as a white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 443.2 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: (R)-tert-Butyl 1-(3-methoxy-4-(2-(methylamino)pyridin-4-yl)phenylamino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-ylcarbamate (60 mg, 0.136 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) and cooled to 0 °C. To this solution was added TFA (0.104 mL, 1.356 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A) to afford 52 (25 mg, 0.055 mmol, 40% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD-d4) δ 7.77 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 1H), 7.60 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.47 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.31 (dd, J = 8.4, 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.18 (s, 1H), 7.09 (dd, J = 6.9, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.90–3.87 (m, 1H), 3.87 (s, 3H), 3.03 (s, 3H), 2.03 (ddd, J = 9.7, 6.5, 3.4 Hz, 1H), 1.71–1.58 (m, 1H), 1.32–1.19 (m, 1H), 1.09 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H), 0.99 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). MS (ESI) m/z: 343.2 [(M + H)+. HPLC purity: 92.3%, tR = 6.62 min (method E); 95.5%, tR = 6.79 (method F).
    (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(pyridin-3-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (53)
    Compound 53 was prepared from 3-methoxy-4-(pyridin-3-yl)aniline (89h) (135 mg, 0.674 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (234 mg, 1.01 mmol) according to the representative two-step procedure described for the synthesis of 11 from 67. The product was purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A).     (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-methoxy-4-(pyrimidin-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide, TFA (54)
    Step 1: To a mixture of (R)-tert-butyl (1-((4-bromo-3-methoxyphenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (76) (200 mg, 0.482 mmol), 5-pyrimidinylboronic acid (65.6 mg, 0.530 mmol), and tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(0) (27.8 mg, 0.024 mmol) in toluene (4 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) under N2 was added a solution of Na2CO3 (153 mg, 1.45 mmol) in water (1 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at reflux for 12 h. The mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel containing water. The aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 25 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10–50% EtOAc in hexanes, 40 g column) to afford (R)-tert-butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(pyrimidin-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (90 mg, 0.217 mmol, 45% yield) as a white solid. MS (ESI) m/z: 415.4 (M + H)+.
    Step 2: To a solution of (R)-tert-butyl (1-((3-methoxy-4-(pyrimidin-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (90 mg, 0.217 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) at 0 °C was added TFA (1 mL, 12.98 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h.     (R)-2-Amino-4-methyl-N-(4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)pentanamide, TFA (55)
    Compound 55 was prepared from 4-(oxazol-5-yl)aniline (200 mg, 1.25 mmol) and (R)-2-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)-4-methylpentanoic acid (433 mg, 1.87 mmol) in a similar fashion as described for the two-step synthesis of 11 from 67. The product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% MeOH in CH2Cl2) to afford 55 (264 mg, 0.668 mmol, 94% yield) as a yellow solid.     (R)-2-Amino-4-methyl-N-(3-methyl-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)pentanamide (56)
    To a solution of (R)-tert-butyl (4-methyl-1-((3-methyl-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate (95) (58 mg, 0.150 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added TFA (0.5 mL, 6.49 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated and purified by preparative reverse phase HPLC (method A). The organic solvent was removed in vacuo, and the product was taken up in EtOAc and converted to the free base by washing with saturated aqueous K2CO3.     (R)-2-Amino-N-(3-ethyl-4-(oxazol-5-yl)phenyl)-4-methylpentanamide (57)
